title: Tensile structure
text:
A tensile structure is a <a href="construction">construction</a> of elements carrying only <a href="tension%20%28physics%29">tension</a> and no <a href="compression%20%28physical%29">compression</a> or <a href="bending">bending</a>. The term "tensile" should not be confused with <a href="tensegrity">tensegrity</a>, which is a structural form with both tension and compression elements.
Tensile structures are the most common type of <a href="thin-shell%20structure">thin-shell structure</a>s.
Most tensile structures are supported by some form of compression or bending elements, such as masts (as in <a href="The%20O2%20%28London%29">The O2</a>, formerly the <a href="Millennium%20Dome">Millennium Dome</a>), compression rings or beams.
A <a href="Tension%20fabric%20building">tensile membrane structure</a> is most often used as a <a href="roof">roof</a>, as they can economically and attractively span large distances. Tensile membrane structures may also be used as complete buildings, with a few common applications being sports facilities, warehousing and storage buildings, and exhibition venues.
History.
This form of construction has only become more rigorously analyzed and widespread in large structures in the latter part of the twentieth century. Tensile structures have long been used in <a href="tent">tent</a>s, where the <a href="guy%20rope">guy rope</a>s and tent poles provide pre-tension to the fabric and allow it to withstand loads.
Russian engineer <a href="Vladimir%20Shukhov">Vladimir Shukhov</a> was one of the first to develop practical calculations of stresses and deformations of tensile structures, shells and membranes. Shukhov designed eight tensile structures and <a href="thin-shell%20structure">thin-shell structure</a>s exhibition pavilions for the <a href="Nizhny%20Novgorod%20Fair%20of%201896">Nizhny Novgorod Fair of 1896</a>, covering the area of 27,000 square meters. A more recent large-scale use of a membrane-covered tensile structure is the <a href="Sidney%20Myer%20Music%20Bowl">Sidney Myer Music Bowl</a>, constructed in 1958.
<a href="Antonio%20Gaudi">Antonio Gaudi</a> used the concept in reverse to create a compression-only structure for the <a href="Colonia%20Guell%20Church">Colonia Guell Church</a>. He created a hanging tensile model of the church to calculate the compression forces and to experimentally determine the column and vault geometries.
The concept was later championed by <a href="Germany">German</a> architect and engineer <a href="Frei%20Otto">Frei Otto</a>, whose first use of the idea was in the construction of the <a href="Expo%2067%20pavilions%23National%20pavilions">West German pavilion at Expo 67</a> in Montreal. Otto next used the idea for the roof of the Olympic Stadium for the <a href="1972%20Summer%20Olympics">1972 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="Munich">Munich</a>.
Since the 1960s, <a href="tension%20%28mechanics%29">tensile</a> structures have been promoted by <a href="design">design</a>ers and <a href="engineer">engineer</a>s such as <a href="Ove%20Arup">Ove Arup</a>, <a href="Buro%20Happold">Buro Happold</a>, Walter Bird of <a href="Taiyo%20Kogyo%20Corporation%23Birdair">Birdair, Inc.</a>, <a href="Frei%20Otto">Frei Otto</a>, <a href="Mahmoud%20Bodo%20Rasch">Mahmoud Bodo Rasch</a>, <a href="Eero%20Saarinen">Eero Saarinen</a>, <a href="Horst%20Berger">Horst Berger</a>, <a href="Matthew%20Nowicki">Matthew Nowicki</a>, <a href="Jorg%20Schlaich">Jörg Schlaich</a>, the duo of <a href="Nicholas%20Goldsmith">Nicholas Goldsmith</a> & <a href="Todd%20Dalland">Todd Dalland</a> at <a href="FTL%20Design%20%26amp%3B%20Engineering%20Studio">FTL Design & Engineering Studio</a> and <a href="David%20Geiger">David Geiger</a>.
Steady technological progress has increased the popularity of fabric-roofed structures. The low weight of the materials makes construction easier and cheaper than standard designs, especially when vast open spaces have to be covered.
Cable and membrane structures.
Membrane materials.
Common materials for doubly curved fabric structures are <a href="PTFE">PTFE</a>-coated <a href="fiberglass">fiberglass</a> and <a href="Polyvinyl%20chloride">PVC</a>-coated <a href="polyester">polyester</a>. These are woven materials with different strengths in different directions. The <a href="Warp%20%28weaving%29">warp</a> fibers (those fibers which are originally straight—equivalent to the starting fibers on a loom) can carry greater load than the <a href="weft">weft</a> or fill fibers, which are woven between the warp fibers.
Other structures make use of <a href="ETFE">ETFE</a> film, either as single layer or in cushion form (which can be inflated, to provide good insulation properties or for aesthetic effect—as on the <a href="Allianz%20Arena">Allianz Arena</a> in <a href="Munich">Munich</a>). ETFE cushions can also be etched with patterns in order to let different levels of light through when inflated to different levels.
In daylight, fabric membrane translucency offers soft diffused naturally lit spaces, while at night, artificial lighting can be used to create an ambient exterior luminescence. They are most often supported by a structural frame as they cannot derive their strength from double curvature.
Cables.
Cables can be of <a href="mild%20steel">mild steel</a>, <a href="High-strength%20low-alloy%20steel">high strength steel</a> (drawn carbon steel), <a href="stainless%20steel">stainless steel</a>, <a href="polyester">polyester</a> or <a href="Aramid">aramid fibres</a>. Structural cables are made of a series of small strands twisted or bound together to form a much larger cable. Steel cables are either spiral strand, where circular rods are twisted together and "glued" using a polymer, or locked coil strand, where individual interlocking steel strands form the cable (often with a spiral strand core).
Spiral strand is slightly weaker than locked coil strand. Steel spiral strand cables have a <a href="Young%27s%20modulus">Young's modulus</a>, "E" of 150±10 kN/mm² (or 150±10 <a href="gigapascal">GPa</a>) and come in sizes from 3 to 90 mm diameter. Spiral strand suffers from construction stretch, where the strands compact when the cable is loaded. This is normally removed by pre-stretching the cable and cycling the load up and down to 45% of the ultimate tensile load.
Locked coil strand typically has a Young's Modulus of 160±10 kN/mm² and comes in sizes from 20 mm to 160 mm diameter.

Structural forms.
<a href="Air-supported%20structure">Air-supported structure</a>s are a form of tensile structures where the fabric envelope is supported by pressurised air only.
The majority of fabric structures derive their strength from their doubly curved shape. By forcing the fabric to take on double-curvature the fabric gains sufficient <a href="stiffness">stiffness</a> to withstand the loads it is subjected to (for example <a href="wind">wind</a> and <a href="snow">snow</a> loads). In order to induce an adequately doubly curved form it is most often necessary to pretension or prestress the fabric or its supporting structure.
Form-finding.
The behaviour of structures which depend upon prestress to attain their strength is non-linear, so anything other than a very simple cable has, until the 1990s, been very difficult to design. The most common way to design doubly curved fabric structures was to construct scale models of the final buildings in order to understand their behaviour and to conduct form-finding exercises. Such scale models often employed stocking material or tights, or soap film, as they behave in a very similar way to structural fabrics (they cannot carry shear).
Soap films have uniform stress in every direction and require a closed boundary to form. They naturally form a minimal surface—the form with minimal area and embodying minimal energy. They are however very difficult to measure. For a large film, its weight can seriously affect its form.

It is important that the final form will not allow <a href="ponding">ponding</a> of water, as this can deform the membrane and lead to local failure or progressive failure of the entire structure.
Snow loading can be a serious problem for membrane structure, as the snow often will not flow off the structure as water will. For example, this has in the past caused the (temporary) collapse of the <a href="Hubert%20H.%20Humphrey%20Metrodome">Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome</a>, an air-inflated structure in <a href="Minneapolis%2C%20Minnesota">Minneapolis, Minnesota</a>. Some structures prone to <a href="ponding">ponding</a> use heating to melt snow which settles on them.
There are many different doubly curved forms, many of which have special mathematical properties. The most basic doubly curved from is the saddle shape, which can be a <a href="hyperbolic%20paraboloid">hyperbolic paraboloid</a> (not all saddle shapes are hyperbolic paraboloids). This is a double <a href="ruled%20surface">ruled surface</a> and is often used in both in lightweight shell structures (see <a href="hyperboloid%20structures">hyperboloid structures</a>). True ruled surfaces are rarely found in tensile structures. Other forms are <a href="http%3A//en.wiktionary.org/wiki/anticlastic">anticlastic</a> saddles, various radial, conical tent forms and any combination of them.
Pretension.
Pretension is tension artificially induced in the structural elements in addition to any self-weight or imposed loads they may carry. It is used to ensure that the normally very flexible structural elements remain stiff under all possible loads.
A day to day example of pretension is a shelving unit supported by wires running from floor to ceiling. The wires hold the shelves in place because they are tensioned – if the wires were slack the system would not work.
Pretension can be applied to a membrane by stretching it from its edges or by pretensioning cables which support it and hence changing its shape. The level of pretension applied determines the shape of a membrane structure.
Alternative form-finding approach.
The alternative approximated approach to the form-finding problem solution is based on the total energy balance of a grid-nodal system. Due to its physical meaning this approach is called the <a href="Stretched%20grid%20method">Stretched Grid Method (SGM)</a>.
